text: before we get into today's podcast I
wanted to share that Yukon London
returns April 7 to 9
2025 Learn what's next from worldclass
leaders pushing the boundaries You'll
learn actionable insights from senior
software developers working on real
world projects across multiple domains
Learn more at qconlondon.com
[Music]
Good day folks This is Shane Hasty for
the InfoQ Engineering Culture podcast
Today I'm sitting down with Claire Bow
from Launch Darkly Cla welcome Thanks
for taking the time to talk to us today
Thanks so much for having me So my
normal starting point in these
conversations would be who's CLA That's
maybe a question I need to ask myself on
a daily basis Who is Claire In the
context of this conversation I am Claire
Vo I'm the chief product and technology
officer at Launch Darkley I lead our
entire technology organization So not
just engineering but product management
design data I even you know pretty
surprisingly have a couple sellers on
the team for our new incubation products
So I have a pretty broad remit but
functionally my job is to build a really
high performing team where we can make
great investments in R&D and bring great
products to our customers and create
value for the company What is a
high-erforming team today It's a really
great question I mean for me I think
about performance from the lens of our
ultimate goal And to me our ultimate
goal is to solve hard problems for
customers that have value to those
customers that have commercial markets
for them and that can build enterprise
value for the company And so to me a
team that is building towards our
ultimate goal which is really customer
centric and valuedriven is what I like
to see in engineering organizations Of
course we want technical excellence Of
course we want
camaraderie and culture and engagement
Of course we want innovation And of
course we want to attract competitive
talent But at the end of the day that is
a means to the end And we really like to
say customer centric and what we're
trying to achieve for our colleagues in
the business Customer centric As an
engineer how do I become customer
centric Well lucky for us our customers
are engineers So we're in a really
privileged spot Launch Darkly is the
leading feature management
experimentation platform in the market
We serve engineers That's our job We
build dev tools for engineers We build
for builders That's actually one of the
things that attracted me to Launch
Darkly is it's really candidly fun to be
able to build for builders and building
technical tools for technical folks is
very interesting So one whether you eat
your own dog food or drink your own
champagne we are power users of Launch
Darkly at Launch Darkly we use Launch
Darkly to release test optimize our own
code in production We use it for small
things for big things We use all the
features We take advantage of the full
platform So one of the ways we become
customer centric as an organization is
we act as customers And that's not just
the engineering organization Product
managers are expected to use the product
Our designers are expected to use the
product And the product is not just the
UI and the web app It's our SDKs It's
our data export tools All those things
that make up the whole platform So I
would say that's one primary way we're a
little advantaged in being customer
centric But the other way is we stay
very close to customers My expectation
in my organization is that everybody's
having customer conversations live real
humanto human customer conversations
every week That's not just the realm of
our salespeople or customer success team
Engineers need to know their customers
that they go to to discuss their most
challenging scale issues Product
managers need to have a group of
customers they can rely on for early
feedback on products And so we really
stay close to customers So then I think
the third thing is we really bring a
beginner's mindset to our product You
know Launch Directly has been in the
market for over 10 years And in those 10
years you can build up a lot of
tolerance for the sharp edges in your
product or the things that you've kind
of gotten used to clicking around or
hacking around And I really think it's
important for folks to come to their own
products with a beginner mindset look at
it with fresh eyes and think if I knew
nothing about Launch Darkly would this
be easy to do So those are just a couple
ways that we're really customer- centric
in my organization You said make a great
culture What does that feel like What
does that look like Yeah So it's really
funny I have this you know fancy se-le
title and tend to go into growth and
scale stage startups so much later stage
startups and everybody thinks that I get
hired to make teams act like a big
company You know I come in as the
grown-up and I say "Okay this is how
you're supposed to run an engineering
organization at scale or a product
organization at scale etc." And of
course my leaders and my team across the
board want to do things to
professionalize the way we operate and
make sure that we're showing up for
customers with stability and pace All
those things are great and I get hired
to remind the team to operate like a
startup So to me a great culture is one
that is very close to customers that
moves fast where there are builders in
the team who want to bring their you
know technical and intellectual and
creative skills to problems people have
And so I think a culture that is very
close to how a startup would operate
Lower process lower BS lower politics
focus on the customer focus on building
have fun Those to me are the cultures I
thrive in Whether or not that's the best
culture or not that is the culture that
I prefer to operate in And then sort of
the non-negotiable is as I said upfront
high performance All of that does not
matter unfortunately unless we build
great products that have market
acceptance that can grow the company to
the ambitions that we have And so I do
bring to great cultures a focus on what
really is our job because I think a lot
of times teams lose sight of that They
think their job is to do the work that
gets them promoted or their job is to do
the work to make them look good in front
of executive and none of that is
actually their job Their job is to help
us build a great business and have an
impact on users And I think that
centricity about the job to be done is
really important in great cultures You
also when we were chatting earlier spoke
about a culture of
experimentation How does that play out
Yeah So you know what I really think is
to build great products you have to be
quite hypothesisdriven and you have to
build test iterate over time One of my
things that I say commonly is know
genius product managers And what I mean
by no genius product managers is product
managers can hone product sense and
build intuition and have experience that
helps them narrow the surface area of
the right problem to solve But the
reality is we have to remain humbled by
users and be able to be humbled by the
market And so it is less important to be
right out the gate and more important to
be fast out the gate and listen to what
users say And so I really do think it's
important that we approach every build
as a hypothesis I believe that there's a
great market here because what I know is
that this data tells us there's an
opportunity and I think we can do X by
building Y And it's a perfectly valid
hypothesis And then you have to have two
things to make this culture of
experimentation work You have to have
real intellectual honesty and
accountability We had a hypothesis Are
we really holding ourselves accountable
to that outcome I'm sure you like I have
have been in teams where everybody says
yes we're going to hit this OKR or this
goal and I have this beautiful strategy
and plan to do it and then you build the
beautiful strategy and the plan in the
end you don't really hit the OKR and
people say oh well you know there's this
excuse and that excuse but you really
have to have a culture of accountability
we said we were going to do something
did we do it and if we didn't do it
let's understand the why the second
thing you really have to have is uh
tolerance for failure which is the
organization has to be resilient enough
to tolerate getting it wrong That means
people have to be okay with being wrong
They have to be okay with saying my
hypothesis was incorrect And the
organization itself actually has to
embrace people that can do that because
those are the folks that have the sort
of
iterative scrappy mindset that's really
going to get you moving in the right
direction with setbacks And so I think
those two things of being sort of like
intellectually honest and accountable
coupled with a high tolerance of failure
and a hypothesis mindset in a team that
moves fast you get to the right answer
quickly and then you're pretty
unstoppable You have both product and
engineering under one umbrella Yes most
organizations don't do that You know
more and more are but the CPTO role is
relatively rare I've actually done it
twice now So you know I've I've had a
couple revs at this particular role
Here's where I think it works well I
think the technology team or at least
that's what we call it Some folks call
it EPD we call it technology I've worked
at other companies that have cute little
names for it but that sort of triad of
functional teams Having a singular
identity I think is really healthy for
culture The idea that engineering and
product are inherently at odds that
design is always an afterthought I don't
think that's necessary I think it is
often a reflection of how organizations
are run under siloed executives So I
really believe that whether or not it's
reporting to me a singular identity as
an organization that represents the R&D
investment in a company is very healthy
It creates better collaboration It
creates more innovation It allows you to
identify and overcome friction within
teams It sets a standard talent bar
across all those orgs So I think it's
very healthy and I've seen it play out I
also think in certain organizations it
can be really helpful for the CEO as I
say to have a single person to hold
accountability for R&D Especially if
like at launch darkly we have a CEO that
is not the founder It can be very very
helpful to have an executive that
represents the full investment in R&D
the team the technology and the product
at the executive level There's sort of
full accountability across that
investment which in most software teams
is the biggest investment in the company
So I think from executive organization
perspective it can be useful but I think
the skill sets are pretty rare and it
takes a certain type to be able to do it
I have a technical background I've I'm
classic generalist I've been a founder
I've actually done revs in all these
organizations because I myself have the
personality of curiosity and learning I
have worked in startups which means you
get exposed to a lot of things So I've
built up the scale operational
experience technical expertise and you
know strategy experience to be able to
operate across all these functions And
then of course I have amazing leaders
across those teams But you know I have
people that report to me that say I I
never want I never want your job I don't
want the whole the whole thing That
seems that seems kind of hard So there's
definitely folks that love the sort of
specialty you know SVP product SVP
engineering role But I do think from an
identity perspective from an R&D
investment perspective and for certain
types it can be a really functional
structure for a software company Down at
the place where the work gets done how
do we get the product and engineering
folks working well together I think
there's a couple things and you forgot
one design Everybody always forgets
design So I have to I mean that's the
other thing that I always do is I'm like
D is part of EPD So you know I think
there's been a lot of thought around
this classic EPD triad engineering
product and design as shephardds for
building a product experience I think
that continues to be true but you know
down at the team level how do you
actually make that happen Well one I do
think you have to have true triad level
accountability and parody on teams So
product doesn't lead everybody else
product engineering and design jointly
are the leads for an initiative And then
the second thing that I think folks
forget that we do culturally is that
doesn't mean they're siloed That means
they're a cohesive unit And we have a
operating principle in our technology
organization called there are no lanes
And what do we mean by there are no
lanes You don't stay in your lane and
you don't expect others to stay in their
lane There are no lanes We have a shared
goal We are a team We have skills that
vary And if it makes sense for me to
help in your lane I have permission and
accountability to do so And so there's
some pretty interesting examples of this
in this new world of AI where designers
can start to build code and prototypes
and engineers can start to generate
product requirements and product
managers can start to wireframe and do
some really interesting design work with
these AI tools And rather than saying no
that's design's job or no that's product
job what we're embracing is this
flexible creativity and skill set in our
teams which allows us to move faster and
build ultimately better products So
those are kind of the two things I think
parody at the lead level and then real
embrace of this one team mindset you
touched on AI What is happening with the
adoption of and we're in many ways very
early in the AI revolution but what's
happening in that team level you
mentioned using some of the tools It's a
combination of tremendous excitement and
a slow pace of adoption And so you know
I have a very unique point of view on
this I am probably what one would call
an AI maximalist I am not very
riskaverse around this topic I think in
fact most teams are moving too slow
against becoming more AIdriven or AI
native We've been fairly aggressive in
our adoption and experimentation And
again there's that word experimentation
Our experimentation with different AI
tools because I really believe that
fundamentally how software is built is
changing And I don't mean over 10 years
I mean over 18 months It is just night
and day The cost of building is
collapsing The way we build is
collapsing The tools we use are changing
And you know I really take the approach
that I should not build the for example
engineering organization of January 2025
I should not build that team I should
think cast forward 5 or 10 years What is
this team actually going to look like
How are they going to operate What is
the world going to look like And work
back into what do we need to do now to
be world class then So I'm really really
very much on the edge I think what's
happening at the ends at the leaf is
experimentation and pilots So I think
there is increasing acknowledgement that
for example coding co-pilots and coding
agents have a place in the stack There
is a risk and compliance framework that
can accept these as part of scaled
engineering organizations So you can get
over that hurdle both from a security
and an IP perspective relatively well at
this point especially with the larger
foundation model providers and then it's
well what the heck do I do with this
thing and how does it change how we work
and my general approach has been to one
allocate budget to it so I don't think
you can experiment without money so we
put aside money for it even if it gets
wasted it's worthwhile because we learn
two name people accountable for every
experiment and have them artic
articulate what the outcome of that
experiment would be And then three it's
funny to say internally but build in
public which is we are very open with
our experimentation in using these AI
tools We share the good we share the bad
We have a Slack channel called Project
Building with AI You know people post I
tried to have Cursor do this and it was
amazing I tried to have Devon do that
and it failed I tried to use Vzero to do
this and it was amazing I tried to have
ChatGpt do that and it failed That sort
of very open and again intellectually
honest assessment allows us to identify
opportunities to really transform how we
build products here at launch directly
So I think there will be increasing
excitement I am definitely driving it
both tops down and bottoms up and we're
seeing real value So there's a there
there So you mentioned building the team
for three five 10 years What is that
team going to be Oh I have so many
opinions on it My real hypothesis is
that teams will largely be led by what
I'm calling the AI powered triple threat
Somebody who is fluent enough across
technology product and design to
actually take those three roles and
collapse them into one and be a singular
leader for a team or a business unit I
think that model is really starting to
show up in my mind and it'll be
interesting to see if it actually shows
up in organization charts I think you
will have teams that are combinations of
humans and agents orchestrating across
workflows and I think those teams will
be building a lot of product So I
actually in addition to being an AI
maximalist I'm an optimist I think you
know technology has generally only
pushed us forward in the world and
building sort of an amazing world with
amazing product and amazing economic
impact and therefore amazing human
impact And so I think we'll see a lot of
really really neat things be built but I
think the shapes of the teams are going
to look so different What do we need to
do to help the people of today become
those team members One we need to invest
in learning and development like this is
a real upskilling moment and it's really
funny to take teams where folks have
spent a tremendous amount of time in
their academic training and then their
professional training These are senior
engineers and staff engineers and
principal product managers who are so
adept in what they do and say guess what
you are actually not going to know how
to do your job in 2 years and I need to
reskill you in how this is actually
going to look So I do think there is
this learning and development motion
that needs to happen And then I think
there is cultural things that if you do
not have it will make it very hard for
you to get here And again there are
things that I have said are important
before and I'll continue to say you have
to have a culture of experimentation You
have to be willing to try things You
have to have a willingness to fail and
admit where things are working and where
they're not And then you have to I think
in general have an optimistic outlook
People can get very afraid about how
changes will impact their jobs their
livelihoods I think it is naive to
ignore that and claim that that is not
something that is on people's minds And
at the same time I think leaders have
the opportunity to frame and build
companies that have tremendous upside
for the individuals that participate in
them and professional personal economic
you know just core satisfaction But I
don't think if leaders ignore that piece
of it they will be very successful You
mentioned reskill you mentioned the
culture What are the skills So there's a
couple things that I think about One
there is actually from a technical
perspective you were talking about
engineering understanding how these
models operate how they operate inside
products what their tool sets are And
there's functionally this whole world of
like AI engineering that I think is a
skill that like technically needs to be
built in both product engineer actually
product engineering and design teams
That is just a whole new surface area of
how we build software It's very
different The second skill is how do I
build alongside co-pilots agents and AI
enabled tools And what's really
interesting is it is muscle memory you
have to break not value you have to
prove And so what I mean by that is
simple example everybody knows if they
go to chat they can accelerate some part
of their day I think people have
generally accepted that they've proven
it to theel they just forget to go to
chachi pt like they forget to make that
part of their workflow because they're
so used when I have a task to do this is
the place I go to do it and then I'm you
know 75% down the path and I'm almost
done so I'll just do it And so I do
think there's this workflow operations
model that you really have to somebody
went to lunch called it like whole team
behavior modification You really have to
get the whole team to start doing
handoffs and work in a very different
way I think that's pretty interesting
And then you know the third thing is
there are these tools themselves that
have a learning curve and let's just
take for example one of these AI powered
IDEs like cursor People get bad outcomes
from cursor because they don't use
cursor well because they have not
learned to use a conversational coding
co-pilot well There's setup you have to
do There's practices you have to do And
so I think there is actually learning
the tools themselves enough to get value
out of them that I also think is very
important But those tools are changing
so fast Yeah But they feel like the
skills are replicable across tools A lot
of good stuff there What haven't I asked
you that I should have done You know one
of the things that I don't think we
talked about is you know maybe how it's
going to change geography and how teams
are composed across time zones and what
it means I mean you and I are speaking
from quite a distance and you know
postco we've gone through this radical
reimagining that what work looks like
and I think that AI itself will have
impacts on who you hire where you hire
when they work how they work I actually
had a moment this morning So I'm pretty
experimental and I use Cognition Labs
Devon co-pilot and this morning it was
so funny because it works synchronously
right It does planning and it's in an
agent so it works synchronously is
working and clicking off tasks but it is
a co-pilot in some extent And so
occasionally Devon will ask me hey can
you review this PR or I need this
environment variable set up All those
sorts of things And I was thinking
through this challenge of this agent can
work sort of an infinite time space and
I myself am limited by my body And I
actually said to Devon this morning it
was so funny I said "Hey just so you
know I'm gonna go grab a cup of coffee
I'll be back later if you need something
I'm not going to be here And it got my
brain thinking that I think
organizations are not prepared for how
operationally this will cascade out
across their orgs and they're not
playing those sort of like game theory
games of if 10% of my engineering
workforce actually becomes an agent do I
need to like follow the sun coverage on
my human engineering team to keep that
agent team productive And I just maybe I
push it really far and I think about the
future more than other folks do But if
you're for example San Francisco based
or a US-based team how you set up your
team to operate alongside agents can be
a competitive advantage and a strategic
advantage that I don't know if enough
technology leaders are thinking through
So I know you're the people person and
soon enough you will be the people plus
agent person I'm presuming that you you
said I spend my time with the humans and
you know you're going to spend your time
with humans and the prototype humans but
it is really something very interesting
to think about the human interactions
both from a collaboration perspective is
just candidly the operational
perspective is something I think leaders
need to consider Wow Thanks very much If
people want to continue the conversation
where do they find you I am on X and of
course I am on LinkedIn clear vote
Thanks so much Thank you
